action.action-desc: Mr. Tipton introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Natural Resources

form.official-title: To amend the Mineral Leasing Act to require the Secretary of the Interior to develop and publish an all-of-the-above quadrennial Federal onshore energy production strategy to meet domestic energy needs, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Planning for American Energy Act of 2017.

section.header: Onshore domestic energy production strategic plan

subsection.text: The Mineral Leasing Act (30 U.S.C. 181 et seq.) is amended by redesignating section 44 as section 45, and by inserting after section 43 the following:

section.header: Quadrennial Federal Onshore Energy Production Strategy

subsection.header: Requirement To publish Quadrennial Federal Onshore Energy Production Strategy
subsection.text: The Secretary shall develop and publish once every 4 years a Quadrennial Federal Onshore Energy Production Strategy.
In developing the Strategy, the Secretary shall consult with—

paragraph.text: the Administrator of the Energy Information Administration with regard to—

subparagraph.text: the projected energy demands of the United States for the next 30-year period;
the methodology used to arrive at such projection; and
actions to be taken during the next 4-year period with the goal of meeting such demands;

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Agriculture with regard to lands administered by such Secretary; and
the Secretary of Energy with regard to energy transmission, storage, and distribution infrastructure.

subsection.header: State, federally recognized Indian Tribes, local government, and public input
subsection.text: In developing the Strategy, the Secretary shall solicit the input of—

paragraph.text: the State, federally recognized Indian Tribe, or local government where each energy project included in the Strategy is proposed to be located; and

The Strategy shall direct onshore Federal land energy development and department resource allocation in order to promote the energy security and national security of the United States in accordance with the principles of multiple use and sustained yield.

paragraph.header: Projected domestic demand for energy resources
paragraph.text: The Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator of the Energy Information Administration, shall include in the Strategy an estimate, based upon commercial and scientific data, of the projected domestic demand for energy resources over the 30-year period beginning on the date of the publication of such Strategy. The estimate shall be disaggregated by the energy resource types listed in subparagraphs (A) through (H) of paragraph (3) and expressed in British thermal units or me­ga­watts, as appropriate.

The Secretary shall include in the Strategy a domestic strategic production objective based on the estimate in paragraph (2) for the development of the following energy resource types on Federal onshore lands:

subparagraph.text: Electricity, in megawatts, from each of wind, solar, biomass, hydropower, and geothermal energy.
Energy from unconventional energy production, such as oil shale.
Oil, natural gas, coal, and other renewable sources from the Tribal lands of any federally recognized Indian Tribe that elects to participate in facilitating energy production on its lands.
Other energy production technology sources or advancements in energy, as determined by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: In the Strategy, the Secretary shall consider—

subparagraph.text: how Federal lands will contribute to ensuring national energy security, with a goal for increasing energy independence and production during the next 4-year period;
the ability of existing energy transmission, storage, and distribution infrastructure to efficiently utilize energy production from Federal lands; and
the proportion of total energy production derived from Federal land compared to non-Federal land for each of the energy resources listed in subparagraphs (A) through (H) of paragraph (3).

subsection.text: It is the sense of Congress that federally recognized Indian Tribes may elect to set their own production objectives as part of the Strategy. The Secretary shall work in cooperation with any federally recognized Indian Tribe that elects to participate in achieving its own strategic energy objectives.
The Secretary shall submit a report annually to the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate that—

paragraph.text: examines the progress made toward meeting the domestic strategic production objective set forth in the Strategy;

identifies projections for production and capacity installations and any problems with leasing, permitting, siting, or production that may prevent meeting the domestic strategic production objective set forth in the Strategy; and
provides suggestions to address any shortfalls in meeting the domestic strategic production objective set forth in the Strategy.

subsection.text: At least 60 days before publishing a proposed Strategy under this section, the Secretary shall submit such Strategy to the President and to Congress, together with any comments received from States, federally recognized Indian Tribes, and local governments. Such submission shall state why any specific recommendation of a State, federally recognized Indian Tribe, or local government was not accepted.

paragraph.text: The term multiple use has the same meaning given such term in section 103 of the Federal Land and Policy Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1702).
The term Secretary means the Secretary of the Interior, unless the context requires otherwise.
The term Strategy means the Quadrennial Federal Onshore Energy Production Strategy required to be developed and published under subsection (a).

The term strategic and critical energy minerals means minerals that are necessary for the production of energy and the building and maintaining of the energy infrastructure of the United States, including minerals necessary—

subparagraph.text: for pipelines, refining capacity, electrical power generation and transmission, and renewable energy production;
to support domestic manufacturing, including materials used in energy generation, production, and transportation; and
to ensure the national security of the United States.

paragraph.text: The term sustained yield has the same meaning given such term in section 103 of the Federal Land and Policy Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1702).

subsection.text: Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of the Interior shall submit to Congress the first Quadrennial Federal Onshore Energy Production Strategy under the amendment made by subsection (a).
